keywords.documentation: Copies a parameter from the active input buffer to the active output buffer. The parameter remains in the input buffer.
Moves the pointer for the currently active input buffer backward to the first character of the previous parameter.
Moves the output buffer pointer back to the end of the previous field, discarding the characters it moves over.
Specifies a comment line.
Displays one or more fields from the active input buffer.
Moves the input buffer pointer forward to the next parameter in the active input buffer.
Transfers control to another command within a PROC, and continues to execute from that command.
Adds a string of text to the end of the active output buffer, and positions the pointer at the end of the string.

Evaluates a condition and, if it is true, executes the specified PROC command. 
If the command is false, the PROC command does not execute.
***
Replaces the current parameter in the active input buffer with specified text.
Reads input from the terminal and places it in the active input buffer at the position specified by the input buffer pointer.
Reads input from the terminal and places it in the secondary input buffer, replacing the current contents.
Reads a backup medium label from an attached backup medium into the primary input buffer.
Outputs a string of text to the terminal, followed by a carriage return.
Submits the command constructed in the primary output buffer to the TCL command processor.
Clears both input buffers and makes the primary input buffer active. The command can also be used to clear only a portion of the primary input buffer.
Clears both output buffers and makes the primary output buffer active.
Sets the input buffer pointer for the currently active input buffer.
Selects the primary input buffer as the active input buffer, and positions the pointer at the beginning of the buffer.
Selects the secondary input buffer as the currently active input buffer, and positions the pointer at the beginning of the buffer.
Turns off the stack, or secondary output buffer, and makes the primary output buffer active.
Makes the secondary output buffer, or stack, active. The stack holds responses for an interactive processor such as mvBASIC or the Editor.
Formats the display of output on the terminal screen.
Terminates a Proc and returns control to TCL. The X command also marks the end of a local or external subroutine defined with the [ ] (call) command.
Transfers control from one PROC to another PROC.
